Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Resource Mobilization and Network Formation within Forced Migrant Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores network formation and survival strategies among forced migrant populations. Forced migrants who move within and across national borders as a result of events such as conflict, natural or environmental disasters, and famine are a particularly vulnerable part of the world's population. Often living in the margins of their new societies, most live in poverty and face a difficult future. Throughout the U.S., forced migrants are resettled into diverse places but often the specific kinds of challenges they face through the resettlement process are not well recognized. A better understanding of how forced migrants experience displacement and what resources they rely on to secure livelihoods and improve their well-being is critical for developing programs and policies that will improve the outcomes of resettlement efforts and help to build strong communities both in and beyond the U.S. Findings will be disseminated to aid organizations that explore and manage the causes, consequences, and complexities of forced migration. The research also fosters international scientific cooperation, and will broaden participation of an underrepresented group in the sciences.

Daniel Joseph, under the supervision of Dr. Kristin Monroe of the University of Kentucky, will examine what strategies are deployed by displaced persons, facing statelessness and precarious social and economic conditions, to mobilize resources within and across their communities. This research is based in Anse-Ã -Pitres, a Haitian city along the border with the Dominican Republic where thousands of displaced people currently live in makeshift camps. These people, illegal Haitian migrants and Dominicans born of undocumented Haitian descent, were forced from the Dominican Republic in August 2015. The researcher will conduct participant observation and semi-structured interviews over a period of 12 months in different locations including camps, churches, market places, public gatherings, and food distribution sites. Relations with the displaced people and the establishment of networks will be facilitated through coordinating with an on-site relief organization. This research will contribute to theories of agency and conceptualizations of citizenship beyond the juridico-legal framework. Furthermore, insights from this research will help to develop programs and policies aimed at the empowerment of refugees and internally displaced persons.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the research was to understand how Haitian migrants and Dominicans of Haitian origin forced out of the Dominican Republic create livelihood strategies among precarious social and economic conditions and in the face of statelessness through mobilizing resources and forming networks within their communities in Anse-à-Pitres, Haiti and beyond. The research lasted a year and a half between 2016 and 2017. The methods included participant observation through the camps where these people live, participation in public meetings, visits to sites of food distribution, particularly the Catholic Church of downtown Anse-à-Pitres, visits to homes, structured interviews with members of the displaced population, and the administration of focus groups with displaced persons where they spoke about their lived experiences.

Through this research, I found that forced migrants in Anse-à-Pitres are marginalized in several ways. They reside in peripheral areas where they do not interact much with long-term local residents, who continue to see them as a threat to their security and well-being. They face fundamental challenges in their everyday lives in Anse-à-Pitres having to do with severe food insecurity, degrading health conditions in camps, the withdrawal of relief organizations, and the absence of state agencies and suport. The forced migrants live on a day-to-day basis relying on strained resources they mobilize through informal economic practices such as street vending, gathering wood, making charcoal, and becoming day laborers. Most of these informal economic activities take place in the Dominican Republic from where they were expelled, which has created a situation in which these recently displaced are transnationally mobile on a daily basis.

This research advances three main theoretical lines of inquiry. First, it produces a critique of economic theories that tend to consider the economy a distinct aspect of people’s cultural life by showing how the informal economic practices are embedded in people's cultural and moral lives. Moreover, the informal economic practices of forced migrants shaped not only by contemporary global economic processes but also by a colonial history that forced the enslaved into informal economic practices as a means of survival. Second, this research broadens the focus of transnationalism studies by demonstrating the ways in which the underprivileged, not just the privileged, are connected across geographical spheres. For example, unlike many immigrants of the present era who have access to the kinds of technologies which forge transnational connections, this group of forced migrants create transnational ties through their labor mobility back and forth across national borders. The third theoretical line of inquiry involves the theorizing of citizenship beyond the legal scope. By creating developing practices such as illegal border crossings, forced migrants express a form of transnational substantive citizenship that is bolstered through the intervention of international organizations in Anse-à-Pitres.

This project impacts displaced people’s lives in an important way. By opening a space of dialogue for members of the displaced population through methods such as focus groups, this research has included the voices and experiences of forced migrants in such a way that they can be defined and understood not according to a theory of victimology but according to a theory of agency that endows them with the capacity to make and remake their own lives in Anse-à-Pitres, Haiti. This is a theoretical intervention that humanizes displaced people and encourages policy makers to develop programs and policy that emphasize their role as agents in -- rather than recipients of -- development projects.
